A: The problem is likely due to the encoding of the text. You are using UTF-8 to convert the text to bytes, but this might not be the correct encoding for your server. 

Try changing the encoding to ISO-8859-1 (or US-ASCII if you are sure that your text will only contain ASCII characters).

Here is how you can do it:
```kotlin
override fun getByteData(): MutableMap<String, FileDataPart> {
    val params = HashMap<String, FileDataPart>()
    params["file"] = FileDataPart(
        "file$rndInt",
        getBytes(finalInputSteam!!)!!,
        "fffff"
    )
    return params
}

private fun getBytes(input: String): ByteArray? {
    return input.toByteArray(Charset.forName("ISO-8859-1"))
}
```

This should ensure that your text is correctly encoded and sent to the server.

Please note that this solution assumes that your server is configured to accept ISO-8859-1 encoding. If this is not the case, you might need to adjust the encoding accordingly.

Also, make sure that the server is configured to correctly handle the encoding of the text data. If the server is not correctly configured, you might need to adjust the configuration of the server accordingly.

If the problem persists, you might need to check the server logs for more information about the error.

Please note that the solution provided above is a general solution and might need to be adjusted based on the specific requirements of your server and application.
